From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

On 26 October 2017 at 12:36, Adam Gaier adam.ga@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
[...]
>
> What is the current state in terms of benchmarking?

Related: I made an attempt at defining a couple of tasks that were
fast to compute but also difficult enough to be meaningful tests of
how good a given neuro-evolution search implementation is. I
documented what I did here:

   http://sharpneat.sourceforge.net/research/efficacy-sampling.html


> Is cart-pole still a good/common benchmark?

Personally I would say no. I would put it in the same category as XOR,
i.e. it's good as a baseline test to confirm an implementation works
at a basic level, but not a good benchmark overall. Both single and
double pole are solvable with trivially small networks, whereas I
would say the interesting research going on involves more complex
networks.

It's maybe worth looking here too:

    https://gym.openai.com/docs/

I see they have a few cart-pole based experiments, but some more
varied ones too. However, I don't know much about this and whether the
RI/AI community are embracing this or not - anyone know?

Colin
